---

# Lab 2.1: Terraform Essentials

In this lab, you will create Terraform code for configuring providers, creating variables, and creating resources. Then, you will use Terraform commands and a basic workflow to manage cloud infrastructure. All of this will be performed using the deployment server you built in the previous lab.

## Step 1: Creating the Terraform Configuration Code

1. If you have not already done so, connect to your deployment server terminal.

2. Create a folder named terraform, with a subfolder named aws, and below that, a subfolder named getting-started and switch to that folder. You can paste the following code into the terminal if you like. 

| mkdir \~/terraform mkdir \~/terraform/aws mkdir \~/terraform/aws/getting-startedcd \~/terraform/aws/getting-started |
| :---- |

3. In the getting-started folder, create the following files: main.tf, output.tf, provider.tf, variables.tf, and terraform.tfvars. You can use the following command.

| touch main.tf output.tf provider.tf variables.tf terraform.tfvars |
| :---- |

4. Enter ls to verify the files were created. 

5. In the terminal, type **nano variables.tf,** or use the editor of your choice.. Add the following variable definitions to the variables.tf file. 

| variable "project" {   description \= "The AWS Project Name."   type        \= string } variable "region" {   type    \= string   default \= "us-east-1" }  |
| :---- |

6. Save your changes using your choice of editor. (VI, nano) In Nano, type Ctrl+X, then Y, and Enter.

7. To configure the AWS Terraform provider, open the provider.tf file and add the following code using the editor of your choice.

| terraform {   required\_providers {     aws \= {       source  \= "hashicorp/aws"       version \= "6.10.0"     }   } } provider "aws" {   region  \= var.region }  |
| :---- |

   

8. Edit the terraform.tfvars file, substituting your project ID with \<Your Initials\>-project. Save your changes using the editor of your choice.

| project \= "\<initials\>-project" region \= "us-east-1" |
| :---- |

9. You will use Terraform to create a virtual machine. In the main.tf file, add the following Terraform configuration code. Save your changes.

| resource "aws\_instance" "vm" {     ami           \= "ami-0be2609ba883822ec"   instance\_type \= "t2.medium"   tags \= {     Name \= "${var.project}-vm"   } } |
| :---- |

10. Lastly, add the following to the output.tf file. This will just return the external IP address of your server. Save your changes.

| output "public\_ip\_address" {   value       \= aws\_instance.vm.public\_ip   description \= "The public IP address of the server." }  |
| :---- |

## Step 2: Terraform Workflow

1. Using the terminal, enter the following to initialize Terraform.

| terraform init |
| :---- |

2. If you get no errors, type:

| terraform plan |
| :---- |

3. Make sure you have no errors. If you do, fix them. It should tell you that one resource will be added and none will be deleted or changed. Enter the following to deploy your virtual machine. Enter yes when prompted.

| terraform apply |
| :---- |

4. In the AWS console, from the navigation menu, select **EC2**. You should see your machine starting. 

5. In the terminal, after the machine is created, its external IP address should be returned. Verify that it is correct by comparing it to the Public IP shown in the AWS console. 

6. To see the state of your resources, type the following. 

| terraform show |
| :---- |

| Note: There are many more fields shown than the ones that were set in the configuration. Some fields are dynamic and cannot be set in the configuration. In other cases, when a field is not set in the configuration, a default value is used.  |
| :---- |

7. Delete the virtual machine by entering the following, and type yes when prompted.

| terraform destroy |
| :---- |

## Step 3: Managing State

1. Create the virtual machine again by entering the apply command. Add the \-auto-approve parameter to avoid being prompted. 

| terraform apply \-auto-approve |
| :---- |

2. After the machine is created, enter terraform show to view the current configuration. 

3. Now, you will make a change. In the main.tf file, change the machine type from t2-medium to t2-small. 

4. Run terraform plan again. It should tell you one resource will be changed.   
5. Run terraform apply \-auto-approve to make the change.

6. In main.tf, add the following code after the name key-value pair. This will add a tag to the VM that you deployed. 

|       phase \= "testing" |
| :---- |

7. Run terraform plan again. 

8. Run terraform apply \-auto-approve to make the change. 

9. In the AWS console, click your server, then select the **Tags** tab. You should see your Tag.

   ![][image3]

10. In the AWS console, click the **Manage Tags** button. Find the tag and change testing to production. Scroll down and click the **Save** button. 

11. In the terminal, enter terraform refresh. 

12. Now, type terraform show, then scroll up to find your phase label. Notice it has the value “production”.

13. This does not match our configuration. Type terraform plan. It should indicate one resource will be changed. Scroll up and find your label again. The plan should indicate that the label value will be changed back to testing. 

14. Apply the plan. After it is complete, verify that the value was changed by looking at the server details in the AWS console. 

15. Run terraform destroy \-auto-approve to delete what you have created. 

| Note: The completed code is located here: [https://github.com/roitraining/hands-on-terraform/tree/main/aws/getting-started](https://github.com/roitraining/hands-on-terraform/tree/main/aws/getting-started)  |
| :---- |
